meaning: The word 'all' is used to refer to the whole quantity or extent of a particular group or thing. It can mean 'every one of', 'the whole of', or 'completely'.
etymology: The word 'all' originates from the Old English word 'eall', which means 'entire, whole, every'. It is derived from Proto-Germanic *allaz, and is related to Dutch 'al', German 'all', and Old Norse 'allr'.
sentence: All is fair in love and war.
She gave her all to the project.
All that glitters is not gold.
short_stories: In a small village, a wise old man once said, 'All you need is within you.' The villagers pondered this and realized that true wealth and happiness come from within.
A traveler once asked a sage, 'What is the meaning of life?' The sage replied, 'All is one, and one is all. Understand this, and you will find peace.'
poetry: All the world's a stage, / And all the men and women merely players; / They have their exits and their entrances, / And one man in his time plays many parts, / His acts being seven ages. - William Shakespeare
All that we see or seem / Is but a dream within a dream. - Edgar Allan Poe
